body_html: This is intended behavior, unfortunately. The identity op returns a tensor that shares the same memory buffer as the variable, so any update to variable will get reflected in the output of the identity op. If you change the identity op to tf.add(x, 0), you should see the "old" value.
body_text: This is intended behavior, unfortunately. The identity op returns a tensor that shares the same memory buffer as the variable, so any update to variable will get reflected in the output of the identity op. If you change the identity op to tf.add(x, 0), you should see the "old" value.
body: This is intended behavior, unfortunately. The identity op returns a tensor that shares the same memory buffer as the variable, so any update to variable will get reflected in the output of the identity op. If you change the identity op to tf.add(x, 0), you should see the "old" value.
